key_points: The Ever Given container ship was freed from the Suez Canal banks on Monday after being stuck sideways for six days.
Salvage efforts involved powerful tugboats, large-capacity dredgers, and high tides.
30,000 cubic meters of sand were removed, equivalent to about a dozen Olympic-sized swimming pools.
The Ever Given is 1,312 feet long, almost as tall as the Empire State Building.
More than 300 ships were waiting to pass through the canal, with estimates on clearing the backlog ranging from three to more than ten days.
The Suez Canal Authority chairman estimated the canal's daily disruption cost at $15 billion.
The refloating operation used both conventional earthmoving equipment and specialized ships like dredgers and tugboats.
Two dredgers, the 10th of Ramadan and the Mashhour, played a significant role in the operation.
About 14 tugboats were used, benefitting from high tides caused by a full moon.
Over 130 additional vessels were en route to the Suez Canal, adding to the congestion.
